reporting-org.narrative: IHE Delft Institute for Water Education

title.narrative: DGIS - IHE Delft Programmatic Cooperation (DUPC), 2016-2023

description.narrative: Working in partnership on education and training, research and capacity development is a key approach of IHE Delft. This approach has considerably increased the Institute’s and its partners’ impact at the global and local levels, and has been strongly supported by the DGIS IHE Delft Programmatic Cooperation (DUPC). The goal of the DUPC2 programme (2016 - 2023), is to provide tangible contributions in solving water and development challenges worldwide, by equipping people and organisations through sustained and strengthened partnerships in southern and transition countries.

participating-org.narrative: The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs (DGIS)

organisation.narrative: IHE Delft Institute for Water Education

job-title.narrative: Associate Professor of Integrated River Basin Management Coordinator DGIS - UNESCO-IHE Programmatic Cooperation (DUPC)

sector.narrative: Within this programme we identify five themes: 1. Efficient water management, particularly in the agricultural sector 2. Improved catchment area management and safe deltas 3. Access to clean drinking water and basic sanitation 4. Water diplomacy 5. Water scarcity and water related problems related to the refugee crisis in the Middle East

title.narrative: Education: Enhanced quality and accessibility of problem-oriented water education and training programmes in the DUPC focus countries

description.narrative: Enhanced quality and accessibility of problem-oriented water education and training programmes in developing and transition countries, of strategic importance for the respective country as well as Global Campus, including selected joint programmes. Delivery models are evaluated and successful ones are scaled up. Enhanced quality for at least 5 new water training and education programmes of partners and the 7 current joint degree programmes.

title.narrative: Quality assurance systems established and operational for joint degree programmes .

New call has been launched in 2018. New activities have started up in 2019 related to online product development. Indicators will be revised in second half of 2020

title.narrative: Knowledge sharing: Strengthened water and development agenda-setting role of IHE Delft and partners.

description.narrative: Programme results shared and made accessible to wider audiences, as well as targeted knowledge sharing with DGIS, EKNs and other parties. Networks and partnerships supported, as well as the organisation and quality assurance of joint delivery of education and research of the IHE Delft and partners.

title.narrative: Research: Piloting / demonstration projects for technological or social innovations supported
Number of examples of social and technological innovations or adaptations of innovations tested and demonstrated with end-users or agents of change

description.narrative: Examples are based on result ´Problem-oriented scientific knowledge and insights related to the four DUPC themes developed and targeted to agents of change´

title.narrative: Percentage of the members still in contact with each other outside the framework of the Community after 2018

description.narrative: Out of 60 project innovations 16 should be/are successful (is continued with external funding and on a larger scale in the same country or a different one), distributed reasonably across 7 countries and all defined pressing needs. None of the countries and needs is allocated less than 1/3rd of the average investment. Explanatory note: with 7 countries and € 10.5 million (= including co-financing), on average € 1.5 million is available per country; thus in each country a minimum of 1.5/3 = € 0.5 million will be available over 4 years.

comment.narrative: The objective was changed from 50% to 25% of 63 projects should be successful.

Goal reached: 35% is scaling (twice the amount of the pilot), 17% has continued with the business and is applying the innovation, 35% still needs an extra step, 3% did not continue with the pilot, 10% failed. As for distribution over the countries: only in South Sudan we did not reach this goal (due to political reasons). As for distribution over pressing needs: accomplished.

title.narrative: Percentage of the members of the VIA Water Community that are not in the water sector

comment.narrative: 3 - 5 active international communities created around pressing needs

32% maybe. Decision was taken to change the focus in the Community on the project partners, so less focus on non-water actors. 59% of the African partners have indicated the need to continue knowledge exchange after conclusion of the VIA Water programme.

title.narrative: Number of knowledge sharing activities with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs/DGIS and Embassies of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN)
Number of countries per year assisted to ratify or accede to the UN Watercourses Convention (Water Diplomacy theme)

comment.narrative: n 2017, 6 new requests for support. In 2018, Chad and Senegal acceded formally to the ECE WC. In 2019 Ghana agreed with ratification of both conventions. This brings the UNWC to a total of 37 and ECE to 44; 18 countries are party to both, so actually 63 countries are a party to one or both conventions. In 2020, 2 requests for support and advise where acted on.

title.narrative: Number of supports to riparian countries in regional water cooperation processes
Number of 'ready-to-use' applications for farmers and policy officers are developed and distributed

comment.narrative: 1) drought mapping for Africa, also named drought observer, is piloted for three countries – Kenya, Ethiopia, and Mozambique. The beta version is shared via the WaterPIP website. 2) WAPPLUGIN (developed by hackathon team) 3) WaPORACT: open access tools to extract, interpret, analyse and visualise geodata to improve WO.

title.narrative: Number of institutions that use the FAO database to measure water productivity

comment.narrative: At least 19 institutions are using WaPOR for WP on a regular basis. Through webinars, masterclasses, and open courseware more than 500 institutions in Africa and MENA region have been introduced to water productivity and WaPOR. 5 institutions are classified as WaterPIP knowledge hubs (3) and WaterPIP service centres (3) – (one overlap)

title.narrative: Number of projects that use the FAO database to monitor water productivity

comment.narrative: WP analyses using WaPOR implemented for 26 case studies across 8 countries.

title.narrative: Knowledge sharing: Networks and partnerships supported, some existing networks supported in transition to fully functional, sustainable and independent networks

comment.narrative: 60 knowledge products finalized & 20 tools/templates/guideline
